lg.l: By Dean Swift.
How shall I now the nine Invoke
Since all my Comfort's crack'd & Broke?
Then let my sorrows have some vent
Proportion'd to my Discontent.
In all affairs of Humane life,
So Intermixt with Ioy and Strife
My Mug still sweeten'd all my care
My sorrows still were drowned there.
This with an Honest, Iolly friend,
To anxious thoughts cou'd put an end,
Which still clos'd up the Toils of Day,
And made the minutes Gl\i·overwriting·y\de away
But now I have no mug to Drink,
Nor scarce the power to write, or think;
Asist ye Nymphs with wit and Skill
A Native of Parnassus Hill,
Who now Implores the Sacred Nine
To raise his thoughts in every Line.
Your property is not to stint,
Or give a Mug with Nothing In't
Since Bards are Subject to be Dry,
We beg before our Skill we try,
A Draught of the Castalian Spring,
To clear our Pipes before we Sing.
This Mug which I lament in tears
has serv'd me well for many Years.
That Usefull peace of Furniture,·\del·In·broke\
Is Broke, and Shatter'd, past all cure.
Nor can it e'er be Hoop'd with Tin
As other Broken Mugs have been;
Whose Ruptures cur'd by tinkers truss,
Are still of special use to us.
But now alass tis all in vain
To Join thy particles again
What Cost wou'd I on thee bestow
To have the Now in Statu quo?
Thou Mug the Subject of My Song,
Shou'dst not be still nor Empty long.
In Silver Hoops thou Shou'dst appear,
Well tip'd and frothing full of Bear
Whose Fragrant Bubles gently fall
Till by Degrees contracted Small,
they on thy Centre, form a Rose,
So Gratefull to our Eyes, and Nose;
Whose Mantling Juice does far out Shine
The Sparkling of the Choicest wine.
It was a Family old Mug,
Att which our Friends did often tug;
'twas bought when I was but a Youth,
And Granny says upon her truth
A finer Mug was never Bought,
Altho it cost her but a Groat.
The Potter Surely play'd his Part,
for 'twas a Masterpeice of Art;
He form'd it of well temper'd Stuff,
To make it durable and tough.
The Concave, and the Convex white
Appear'd Most pleasing to the Sight.
Twou'd puzzle Euclid, or Descart
To take Demensions of Each Part.
The base wereon it Stood was round,
the Rest with Various Shapes abound,
Not truely \unreadable del\·Spherical nor Connick
Cylindrical, nor Parabollick,
All from the Bottom to the Ear
Was like the Frustrum of a \Sphre·del\ Sphere
The rest like that of a Cone,
To which was fix'd one ear alone;
Tho one wou'd think another Lug
Wou'd we become so large a Mug.
But be it known unto You, Sirs,
Some Modern wise Geometers,
thought it a Surer way, and Quicker,
To fill the Mug with Humming Liquor
Then handing it from North to South
They took the Gauge by word of Mouth.
For when it went full times Round
By long experience they found,
It held two Quarts by Estimation,
And some few tenths by Calculation.
then to Compleat what they begun
they Inch'd it like a Brewers tun,
And in a Minute wou'd descry
Their several Inches, wet or Dry.
They Estimated near Enough
A Connick, or Cylindrick Hoof,
Whene'er the Mug was on a Stoop
They told the ullage to a Sup.
It serv'd a Double prenticeship
And never got a Crack, or Slip;
Until by chance the other Day,
(To shew the frailty of our Clay)
It Got a Most Unlucky fall,
Which may be warning to us all;
For let us live till Nestor's Age
We must att last Go off the Stage.
'twas made in Anna's Glorious Reign,
And allways kept both neat & clean
her health was often drank thereout
In March, or In October Stout.
It went about Iust with the Sun,
And in a Circle still did run,
Twou'd Drain a Cellar areso deep;
And from an In\u·overwriting·d\ndation keep
That Quarter of the town, you know,
Where High-spring-tides do overflow,
For in a Day twou'd exhale
The Lord knows how much bear & Ale;
Nor wou'd it loose it's virtue Quite,
till it was 9 or 10 at Night.
It was a Plannet without Doubt,
And had its Periodick Times
As Regular as Christ-church-chimes.
Then by Nocturnal observation,
We found its virtue and Pulsation,
(When like the Sea it Ebb'd, and flow'd)
Its various operations shew'd,
And Different Influence on Men,
About the hours of Eight & ten.
Twas on a Day some friends & I
were seated on Parnassus High,
My friends began to hem & Coagh
with voices Hoarse, & very Rough,
By long Debating Pro, & Con,
whether the Earth mov'd or the Sun,
Who writ the Best Philosophy,
Copernicus of Ptolomy.
whether they were not both out done
By Newtons Principles Alone.
Tho now the Mode, tis not my way
To Entertain my friends with Tea.
We Bards dont love our drink to New,
Nor can we Spare the time to Brew.
We use no tea, nor Coffee Here,
They're Both Insipid, and too Dear,
They never can clear up the Brain
or put us in a merry Strain.
To some they Give Ill natur'd fits,
while Base detractors pass for wits,
From whose vile Censure, who is free?
All Suffer by their Rash decree.
I guess'd my Brother Bards were dry,
Then begg'd a Nymph who Lives hard by
To step to Helicon in Haste
and Bring the Mug full of the Best.
In haste as she tripp'd down the Stairs
With Gracefull mein but unawares,
Precipitating on her hoop,
As she ran downwards made her Stoop.
Down fell the Nymph, the Mug, and All,
The Loss was great, and great the fall.
The Nymph return'd with nimble foot,
But got her fingers Sorely Cut.
The tidings told with Panting Breath,
How she escap'd a Sudden Death.
The shatter'd Limbs────── oh! dire mishap!
She Brought up gather'd in her Lap,
With Fractures of the Mug so Small,
No art cou'd e'er Cement them all.
Thou Best of Mugs, Adieu, Adieu,
Since I am Doom'd to follow You,
I am But Clay, and so wert thou.
when I go off, or where, or How,
I can not tell; but Still must Strive
To keep this Microcosm alive.
To wet my clay as it Grows Dry,
lest it shou'd into Atoms fly.
